title.rendered: So are the tickets for the World Cup

content.rendered:
BERLIN. – The Organizing Committee for the 2006 World Cup in Germany presented in Kaiserslautern, coinciding with one of the warm-up friendly matches, 100 days before the start of the event, the tickets expected by millions of fans for the matches.

Shortly before the start of the friendly match between the United States and Poland, in Kaiserslautern, one of the twelve venues for the 64 matches in the competition, Wolfgang Niersbach, Vice President of the Organizing Committee, presented a giant ticket to “Goleo VI”, the mascot of the tournament.

The format. This has a yellow and green background with inscriptions in English (group, date, grandstand sector and time) and in German the name of the city and stadium. There is also other information printed in both languages.

The official entry will be “sent to football fans around the world in 3,070,000 copies,” the Committee explained.

Almost all of the tickets were sold out during the different sales phases, the fourth and last of which will end on April 15.

We have to wait. The tickets will be sent to their buyers “only between six and eight weeks before the World Cup”, whose start is set for June 9 in Munich, with the opening match Germany-Costa Rica, and which will end on July 9 with the Berlin end.

They are safe. These entrances have one point in common with the books in the Vatican library: they are equipped with an electronic device with radio frequency. The organizers hope in this way to fight against theft, counterfeiting and the sale of tickets on the black market.

In terms of security, the president of the German police union, Konrad Feiberg, expressed his fear regarding possible acts of violence committed by hooligans, in an interview published this Wednesday, 100 days before the World Cup.

“By all means, we must be prepared,” Freiberg predicted, noting that for England matches, 25,000 “ticketless” fans are expected in Germany.
